course_description: Key themes, problems and topics in Medieval and Renaissance civilizations, including: the development of concepts of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance; notions of decline, renewal, rebirth and reformation in the West; sources and methods of inquiry.

Background to Spanish and Portuguese colonization, exploration, encounter, conquest, settlement, and the birth of colonial institutions up to 1791. The interweaving of world views, cultures, and traditions of Indigenous peoples, Iberians, and enslaved Africans. Topics may include the transformation of politics, societies, economics, culture, religion, spirituality, and land stewardship.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.
instructor: Instructor: Suescun Pozas, Maria Del Carmen

course_description: Interdisciplinary study of the inter-relation and connectedness between the arts, architecture and society in medieval Europe.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: Early to High Renaissance Art & Architecture
course_description: Major monuments, buildings and art works of the period from several critical perspectives including the humanist influence on the arts in Florence and Rome, the issue of patronage and the question of the artist's cultural status.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as ITAL 2P92 and VISA 2P92

course_description: Heroic and chivalric worlds of Europe and how they shaped medieval society. Selections from Beowulf, Anglo-Saxon heroic literature, Old Norse sagas, the lais of Marie de France, Courtly Love and Arthurian-related narratives.
prerequisites: Notes: This course has an experiential learning component . this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Follows the Vikings from their Scandinavian homelands as they raid, trade and settle throughout Europe and the North Atlantic, convert to Christianity, establish new kingdoms and eventually assimilate into medieval Christendom.
prerequisites: Prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): one HIST credit numbered 1(alpha)90 to 2(alpha)99 and one HIST credit numbered 2(alpha)00 to 2(alpha)99 or permission of the instructor.

course_description: Dante's Divine Comedy and the world it created and reflected, focusing on the Inferno. References to relevant visual arts (illustrations and adaptations of the Divine Comedy by such artists as Doré, Rodin and the Pre-Raphaelites).
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as ITAL 3P93

course_description: Interdisciplinary study of the continuities and discontinuities in the history of the Christian Church from the onset of the Middle Ages to the eve of the Protestant reformations. Examination of ecclesiastical authority, Christianity's interactions with Judaism and Islam, changing social structures, monastic reforms, the Crusades, magic, science, religion, the papacy, and the cult of saints and devotion to relics.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_name: The World of the Renaissance & Beyond
course_description: Interdisciplinary study of the primary texts relative to the European Renaissance and global questions that reshape the world, emphasizing the historical, cultural and intellectual legacies of the Renaissance, including literature, religion, philosophy, science, medicine and the history of exploration.
prerequisites: Notes: this course may be offered in multiple modes of delivery. The method of delivery will be listed on the academic timetable, in the applicable term.

course_description: Contesting identity categories resulting from exchanges and interactions of Christians and Muslims in the early modern Mediterranean world, through the study of historical and fictional primary sources.
prerequisites: Crosslisting: also offered as HIST 3Q92 and SPAN 3Q92
